title: ISO 6709 Geographic Coordinate Parser
description: Parse ISO 6709 geographic point locations (latitude, longitude, and optional altitude). ISO 6709 is the international standard for representing geographic coordinates.

motivation.why: ISO 6709 is the international standard for representing geographic point locations. It's used whenever you need to store, transmit, or display precise location data in a standardized format.
useCases: GPS navigation applications - storing waypoints and routes
Photo geotagging - embedding location metadata in images
Location APIs - exchanging coordinate data between systems
GIS databases - storing points of interest

inputFormat.description: ISO 6709 represents coordinates as signed decimal or sexagesimal (DMS) values. Latitude comes first (-90 to +90), followed by longitude (-180 to +180), optional altitude, and optional coordinate reference system.

examples.description: Statue of Liberty - basic latitude/longitude in decimal degrees
Eiffel Tower - note longitude uses leading zeros for alignment
South Pole - negative latitude for southern hemisphere
Statue of Liberty with altitude (93 meters above sea level)
Eiffel Tower with altitude (330m) and coordinate reference system (WGS 84)
Statue of Liberty in sexagesimal (DMS) format: 40°41'21.84"N 74°02'40.92"W

outputFormat.description: The parser returns a GeoCoordinate struct containing the parsed values. Latitude and longitude are stored as f64 (double-precision floats). Altitude and CRS are optional.

latitude.description: Latitude in decimal degrees. Positive = North, Negative = South. Range: -90.0 to +90.0

longitude.description: Longitude in decimal degrees. Positive = East, Negative = West. Range: -180.0 to +180.0

altitude.description: Optional altitude in meters above sea level. Positive = above, Negative = below
